div1.p:
DR. CARTER, YELLOW
FEVER EXPERT, DIES

Assistant Surgeon General of
U. S. Founded Present Mari-
time Quarantine System

Washington, Sept. 14.---(AP)---Dr.
Henry R. Carter, assistant surgeon
general of the United States, died at
his home here today after a long ill-
ness.

Dr. Henry Ross Carter was consid-
ered one of the ranking authorities
on the subject of eyllow fever, being
nominated for the Nobel Prize for his
discoveries in connection with this
work. For the great service he ren-
dered in the construction of the Pamana
Canal Congress created for Dr. Carter
the position of Assistant Surgeon Gen-
eral-at-Large of the United States Pub-
lic Health Service. Another one of his
notable achievements was the founding
of the present maritime quarantine sys-
tem.

A member of a prominent family, Dr.
Carter was born in Caroline County,
Virginia, in 1852. He was graduated
from the University of Virginia as an
engineer in 1873 and a few years later
took his degree in medicine at the Uni-
versity of Maryland. He entered the
Marine Hospital Service in 1879 and
in the fall of that year was ordered to
Ship sland Quarantine Station, in the
Gulf of Mexico, where, at that time,
he saw his first case of yellow fever.
There he began the study of the disease
and laid the foundation of his work for
its control and prevention.

In 1904 Dr. Carter was detailed for
duty in Panama, where he organized
the quarantine service and later served
as director of hosuitals and chairman
of the board of diagnosis. He remained
with the Panama Canal Commission
five years. Panama was freed from
yellow fever a year from the time the
Sanitary Department got to work.

Dr. Carter engaged in hospital, quar-
antine and epidemic work in the United
States, Cuba, the Canal Zone, Russia
and South America. During the World
War he was in charge of the control
of malaria in the extra-cantonment
areas of the camps and in the regions
around the big industrial plants en-
gaged in the production of war ma-
terial. He served as sanitary adviser
to the Peruvian Government in 1920.
He was a member of the Yellow Fever
Council of the International Health
Board of the Rockefeller Foundation.

Among Mr. Carter's achievements
were: The determination of the period
of extrinsic incubation of yellow fever;
the institution of a rational between
the disinfection of vessels and the
detention of their personnel, permitting
the fixing of minimum periods of deten-
tion in quarantine; the encouragement
of uniformity in quarantine practice;
the transfer of the Brunswick, Ga.,
quarantine station to the Federal Gov-
ernment, the first State or municipal
quarantine to be thus surrendered; the
control of numerous yellow fever epi-
demics in the South.
